head.title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Power Line Proposal

hedline.hl1: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Power Line Proposal

body.head.byline: By SEWELL CHAN; Compiled by John Sullivan

abstract.p: Elected officials from Manhattan and Bronx urge Consolidated Edison to reconsider plans to install 9.5-mile underground electric transmission line that would extend from Yonkers into northern Manhattan; officials say power line will have negative impact on vital neighborhood services and residents quality of life; Con Ed spokesman says line is essential to expand capacity of networks (S)

block.p: Elected officials from Manhattan and the Bronx urged Consolidated Edison yesterday to reconsider plans to install a 9.5-mile underground electric transmission line that would extend from Yonkers, along Riverdale Avenue in the Bronx, under the Harlem River and into Inwood, in northern Manhattan. In a statement, the officials said the power line would ''have a severe negative impact on vital neighborhood services and residents' overall quality of life'' and identified an alternative route that they said would be less disruptive. Michael S. Clendenin, a Con Ed spokesman, said that the line was essential to expand the capacity of the networks serving the area and that the proposed route was the most feasible. The State Public Service Commission is expected to decide the issue shortly.

In a statement, the officials said the power line would “have a severe negative impact on vital neighborhood services and residents’ overall quality of life” and identified an alternative route that they said would be less disruptive. Michael S. Clendenin, a Con Ed spokesman, said that the line was essential to expand the capacity of the networks serving the area and that the proposed route was the most feasible. The State Public Service Commission is expected to decide the issue shortly.
